title: two id's
content:
Hi everyone

Ok, I’m going to post two this time...

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080720063824im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/train2_5313.jpg)

To me this looks like the one designed for the telephone book (don’t know why someone would blow it up and put it on a poster...)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080720063824im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/Silo1_6094.jpg)

This one’s from a club flyer.

Thanks for any hints.

Clinton

 [‹ Logo typeface id](http://web.archive.org/web/20080720063824/http:/www.typophile.com/node/45104 "Go to previous forum topic") [One hard and one easy? ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080720063824/http:/www.typophile.com/node/45095 "Go to next forum topic")
author: cisfor

comments.content: First is indeed [Bell Centennial](http://web.archive.org/web/20080720063824/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/linotype/bell_centennial_name_and_number/?sample_text=UX%20QU%20DE&sample_size=74) as you presumed.
Thanks - any ideas for the first one - I know it’s ugly, but that’s why I need to identify it :)
I think Bell Centennial is gorgeous when blown up (I am well aware that that is not its intended purpose).
Really? But the ink traps are so quirky...is that what attracts you?

I agree with Achilles about Bell Centennial’s beauty in big sizes. It is absolutely the quirkyness of the ink traps that attract me. It is what gives it just enough character to be interesting even in a corporate use.
